Suffolk Libraries' most-borrowed books of 2016

Written by Alice Violett · Published Jan 3, 2017

An article in the East Anglian Daily Times has revealed that crime and thriller novels and the books of Roald Dahl were particularly popular among library users in Suffolk last year.

All five of the most-borrowed physical books came from the crime and thriller shelves, with Make Me by Lee Child coming top with 1,847 loans. This was closely followed by Paula Hawkinsâ€™ The Girl On The Train, with 1,804 loans. Even Dogs in the Wild, by Ian Rankin, came third with 1,307 loans.

The five most-borrowed eBooks were more varied. Readers were likely inspired to download Jojo Moyesâ€™ Me Before You, John le CarrÃ©â€™s The Night Manager and JK Rowlingâ€™s Harry Potter and the Cursed Child by the film, TV series and stage show respectively. Also popular were After You, Moyesâ€™ sequel to Me Before You, and The Secret to Not Drowning, by Colette Snowden, which was part of the Brave New Reads programme organised by the Norwich Writers Centre, which we participated in.

Our Big Friendly Read summer reading challenge doubtless helped three Roald Dahl books - The BFG, The Twits and Charlie and the Chocolate Factory - make the five most-borrowed childrenâ€™s books last year. Ever-popular, The Gruffalo, by Julia Donaldson, and Where The Wild Things Are, by Maurice Sendak, complete the list.

See the EADT website for the full article.

The article also features our top tips for 2017. Why not check out our new fiction, non-fiction and childrenâ€™s and young adult titles for January?
